top_categories.workout_context: Tour Divide’s 2745-mile distance demands power production deep into fatigue — the defining challenge of ultra-distance gravel.
Tour Divide’s mixed mountain bike terrain following the continental divide and competitive field demand explosive aerobic capacity — the ability to respond to surges without blowing up.
Every session at Tour Divide intensity builds on this aerobic foundation — the endurance base is the soil everything else grows in.
Racing Tour Divide isn’t just fitness — it’s pacing, fueling, and executing when conditions deteriorate. This workout practices the race itself.
Tour Divide’s gravel roads, forest service roads demands rapid power changes — surge over obstacles, settle on smoother sections, repeat for hours.
At 2745 miles, Tour Divide rewards a massive aerobic engine. This volume work builds the fat-oxidation capacity that keeps you moving when glycogen runs low.
Over-unders train the lactate clearance you’ll need at Tour Divide when surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding hard.
Tour Divide’s 200,000ft of climbing demands seated and standing versatility — the ability to change climbing style as gradient and fatigue dictate.
Tour Divide rewards athletes who can hold sustained power without blowing up — threshold is the engine that drives everything above Zone 2.
Critical power determines how long you can sustain above-threshold efforts at Tour Divide — a higher CP means more time in the red before failure.
Short, violent efforts are unavoidable at Tour Divide — climbs demanding 2-minute maximal efforts, surges to close gaps, attacks on mixed mountain bike terrain following the continental divide.
Blended sessions combine endurance with intensity spikes — exactly what Tour Divide’s mixed mountain bike terrain following the continental divide delivers on race day.

race_overlay.heat: June in Banff, Alberta to Antelope Wells, New Mexico — June start means snow on Canadian/Montana passes, spring mud in Wyoming, afternoon thunderstorms in Colorado's high country, and desert heat in New Mexico. Temperature swings from below freezing at 11,000+ feet to 100°F+ in the desert. Weather changes rapidly at altitude. Wildfires and smoke increasingly common. Begin heat acclimatization 10–14 days before Tour Divide — 20–30min sauna sessions or midday rides in full kit. Pre-load sodium 48 hours out. Target 500–750ml/hr with electrolytes on race day. Race-day realities: Extreme desert heat in final sections.
race_overlay.nutrition: Ultra-distance fueling for 2745 miles: 80–100g carbs/hour from mile 1 — don’t wait until you’re hungry. Practice your exact race-day nutrition in every long training ride. Carry backup calories. 2745 miles burns 8,000–12,000+ calories — you cannot replace them all, but you must try.
race_overlay.altitude: Tour Divide with 200,000ft of climbing, much of it above 8,000ft demands altitude preparation. Arrive 5–7 days early for acclimatization. Expect 5–15% power reduction at altitude. Increase iron intake 4 weeks out. Hydrate aggressively — altitude increases fluid loss by 20–40%. Snow at elevation any time.
race_overlay.terrain: Mixed terrain at Tour Divide requires surface adaptability. Include weekly rides on mixed mountain bike terrain following the continental divide to build confidence. Expect: gravel roads, forest service roads, blm roads.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on Durability, VO2max, and Endurance to prepare you for 2745 miles of mixed mountain bike terrain following the continental divide in Banff, Alberta to Antelope Wells, New Mexico.
